Lukia has a small retail shop, which she has had for five years.  She also has a second business: a restaurant.  

To help expand her business, Lukia has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase essential merchandise like sugar for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Lukia hopes to generate greater profits and buy food for her family.  In the future, Lukia hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase essential goods like sugar for resale.

loans.name: Aigul's Group

texts.en:
Aigul A. is the leader of this group.  She is 37 years old and married to a private entrepreneur.  She has two daughters and a son; all of the children study at school.  

A year ago, with an initial investment of 5,000 KGS, Aigul started a company called “Siberian Health” to sell medicines and cosmetics.  In this way she earns 4,000 KGS per month.  She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase more cosmetics and medicines in order to increase the turnover of her business.  In the future she wants to provide her children with a good education and believes that her job will help to improve the family’s living conditions.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetics and medicines.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
This is Marilyn V., 46, a resident of Admin Site, Tala, Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Gilberto V., a security officer, and is the mother of three children, two of whom are already working. The other child is still studying in college. At this time, Marilyn is working hard to be able to send her youngest child all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Marilyn, as she herself has been a high school graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Marilyn runs a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that sells groceries, toiletries and beverages in small amounts to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, five Philippine pesos' worth of cooking oil or an egg. Her store is located next to her house. Marilyn also sells viands (prepared dishes) just beside her small variety store. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at retail piece rates. She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue running her businesses, she is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan. She plans to use this loan to buy more products such as groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She will also use part of this loan to purchase raw ingredients for her food stall. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Marilyn dreams of being able to give all of her children a good and high-quality education through all of her hard work in her business. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group’s weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of god she receives. 

*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the word of god, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stocks for her store and raw ingredients for her food stall.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam N. is 35 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has three children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Mariam has a medical clinic, which she has had for four years.         

To help expand her business, Mariam has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more medicine and beds for admitting patients.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Mariam hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food for her family.  In the future, Mariam hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more medicine and beds for admitting patients.

loans.name: Emily

texts.en: Emily is 63 years old and a member of the Joy group in Faulu Kenya.  She does livestock farming to earn a living.  She has been in the business for six years and has three employees.  Being a widowed lady with five children, she works hard in her business in order to raise her five children.  Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has learned how to manage her finances and her business at large.  She wants 60,000 KES to buy animal feeds.

loans.use: To buy animal feed

loans.name: Thaer

texts.en:
Thaer, a young man from Tulkarem city, works in a chocolate factory on the production line in Tulkarem, Thaer took out a loan from FATEN to help his brother and contribute to his wedding expenses that his brother couldn't cover himself.

Thaer receives a good salary that will help him repay the loan to FATEN easily. Thaer appears in the picture above.

loans.use: to pay part of his brother's wedding expenses.

loans.name: Zulmira Simao

texts.pt:
Zulmira Simão N. nasceu na cidade de Inhambane, Província de mesmo nome, sul de Moçambique solteira mãe de 4 filhos de idades entre 2 a 10 anos de idade, os 2 mais velhos vaõ a Escola. Fez somente 4ª classe não continuou devido a dificuldades financeiras pelos pais. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e naõ sustenta mais ninguem.

Saiu de Inhambane para Maputo ainda muito nova, veio com os seus pais. Possui um negocio proprio de venda de produtos de primeira necessidade ha mais de 10 anos. Naõ possui empregado e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 3.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e a vezes consegue poupar algum atravez de Xitique(sistema tradicional de Poupança rotativa).

Ja teve empréstimo em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigo que é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu segundo empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 11.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (pedra, areia, cimento e outros) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua casa. O emprestimo anterior foi de 5.500.00mt aplicado na construção da sua casa.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente para poder aceder a outros créditos no futuro. Pretende solicitar novos empréstimos para concluir a sua residencia e confortar a sua familia.
texts.en:
Zulmira Simão N. was born in the city of Inhambane in the province of the same name, in southern Mozambique. She is a single mother of four children between the ages of 2 and 10, the two eldest of whom attend school. She only went through the 4th grade, and wasn't able to continue because of her parents' difficult financial circumstances. She lives in her own home with her family and isn't financially responsible for anyone else.
She and her parents left Inhambane for Maputo when she was very young. She's had her own business selling staple goods for more than 10 years. She doesn't have any employees and brings in about 3000 meticals a month, which is enough to cover household expenses and sometimes even save a little with Xitique (a traditional rotational savings system).
She has received loans from other banks, but learned about Hluvuku from a friend who is also a Hluvuku client. This is her second loan with Hluvuku, in the amount of 11,000 meticals, which she intends to use to purchase construction materials (stone, sand, cement, etc.) to continue building her house. Her previous loan was in the amount of 5500 meticals, which she also used to build her house.
She's committed to paying this loan off on time so that she'll be eligible for others in the future. She intends to request additional loans to finish the house and provide her family with a more comfortable life.

loans.use: to purchase construction material (stone, sand, cement, etc.).

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James has been farming for 15 years, producing a variety of goods but with a concentration on bananas, coffee, and milk which he sells to the local markets in the Nkubu area, Central Kenya. He is married with four children, three of whom are attending school. He also works with a security firm.

Because animal diseases are the biggest challenge in the dairy business, James has requested a loan of 47,250 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says his dairy income will go toward educating his children and improving their living standards by providing for their basic needs. He is also focusing on expanding his coffee plantation.

James is happy about the speed with which Juhudi's loans are processed.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Nidal

texts.en:
Nidal is a Palestinian National Authority employee. He works and lives in Tulkarem city. Nidal has another source of income; he has a small car accessories store in Tulkarem.

Nidal took out a loan from FATEN to pay for house repair expenses.  Niadal's family house needs painting and the ceiling of the kitchen needs fixing.

Nidal was photographed in FATEN's branch in Tulkarem.

loans.use: Pay for house repair expenses.

loans.name: Beldine

texts.en: Beldine is 33 years old and is married with three children.  She operates a poultry farm with one employee.  Through the training offered by Faulu Kenya, she has been enlightened on book keeping, time management and saving money.  This has helped her to run her business well.  She hopes to become a successful business-lady in the future.  With 20,000 KES, she will buy chicks to raise.

loans.use: To buy chicks

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard S. is 35 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  He is married and has four children.  All of his children are currently in school.  Richard has a small retail shop, which he has had for three years.  He also has a second business:  rental houses.  

To help expand his business, Richard has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more essential merchandise like soap and sugar for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Richard hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children.  In the future, Richard hopes to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase more essential goods like soap and sugar for resale.

loans.name: Mousa

texts.en:
Mousa is a young man from Tulkarem. Mousa is a National Palestinian Authority employee who lives and works in Tulkarem. Mousa also is a wedding planner. He doesn't work in wedding planning on a regular basis but it helps him increase his income.

Mousa took out a loan from FATEN to purchase a computer for his sons who are now old enough to start learning to use the computer. Mousa appears in the picture above in FATEN's branch in Tulkarem.

loans.use: to purchase a computer for his sons.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 31 years old and married with two children.  For four years, he has been operating an automotive spare parts shop.  He gained experience for running the business when he was previously employed in an automotive spare parts shop.  

Through Faulu Kenya, he has been economically empowered.   He hopes to expand his shop within five years.  He needs 20,000 Kes to buy synchronizer rings.

loans.use: to buy synchronizer rings

loans.name: Bella

texts.en:
Bella is a 35-year-old married woman with eight children. The oldest child is 15 years old.

Bella has been in the business of raising pigs for 15 years. She plans to use her loan to purchase pig feed. Bella's family also owns a rice farm. She plans to use part of the loan to purchase farm inputs.

Bella works hard to help provide for her family and sustain her children's education.

loans.use: to purchase pig feed and farm inputs

loans.name: Cholpon's Group

texts.en:
Cholpon S. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Kochkor, a nice village in the Isykul region. She is 47 and married to a teacher. She and her husband have three daughters. Two older daughters study at the university and the youngest daughter is in school. 

In order to earn additional money to cover family expenses, Cholpon cultivates potatoes and wheat. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase fuel for sowing wheat. In the near future, she hopes to get a good harvest.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fuel

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase oil and braids for the hair for resale.

loans.name: Damaris

texts.en:
Damaris is 46 years old and married with two children.  She has been selling knitting threads for four years.  With her income, she is able to help her husband with the household expenses.  

She has been motivated to work hard since she joined Faulu Kenya, because she has to pay weekly dues with her group in Faulu Kenya.  She hopes to open an outlet for her business in the future.   She has requested for 30,000 kes to buy knitting threads.

loans.use: to buy knitting threads

loans.name: Bakyara Twekambe Group A In Ibanda

texts.en:
Sarah N. is the leader of Bakyara Twekambe Group A in Ibanda. She is 33 years old, married and has four children aged 7 to 3 years. All of them are in school. 

Sarah sells used clothing and has had a ladies' salon in Bufunda for four years. She is able to make 90,000 UGX as weekly income and this has helped her in taking care of her family and expanding her business. 

Before starting her businesses, she first sold her cow and got start up capital. Sarah needs a loan to be able to purchase ladies' clothing for sale.

loans.use: to purchase ladies' clothing for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a water pump

loans.name: Josephat

texts.en:
Josephat M. N. is a businessman who operates a boutique. He has employed one person in his business, which is two years old. He earns KES 17,000 per month from his job where he works as a mechanic.  

He was previously selling bananas for a living. He hopes to establish a wholesale business within five years. With 50,000 KES, he will buy bags and second-hand clothes.

loans.use: to buy bags and second-hand clothes

loans.name: Dionita

texts.en:
Dionita is a 69-year-old married woman with seven children. The oldest child is 47 years old and is already married.

Dionita said she has been raising pigs for 49 years. She also helps her husband grow rice at their farm. Dionita sells the pigs and rice at the market. She plans to use her loan to purchase pig feed and farm fertilizer.

In the future, Dionita plans to expand her piggery.

loans.use: to purchase pig feed and farm fertilizer

loans.name: Tomas Paipe

texts.pt:
Tomas paipe S. nasceu na cidade de Inhambane, Província de mesmo nome, sul de Moçambique viuvo pai de 3 filhos destes 2 vão a  Escola. Fez 6ª classe não continuou porque não teve mais condições financeiras para ir mais avante. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguem.

Saiu de Inhambane para Boane comprimindo o serviço militar obrigatorio, mais tarde instalou sua residência. Ė desmobilizado militar e pensionista do Ministerio da Defesa e recebe  4.397.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e as vezes consegue poupar uma parte na sua conta bancaria.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigos que saõ clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu quarto empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (arreia, pedra, cimento e outros) para continuar com o melhoramento da sua casa. Os emprestimos anteriores foram  de 2.500.00mt, 5.000.00mt e 15.000.00mt para habitação.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente para poder aceder a outros créditos no futuro. Pretende solicitar novos empréstimos para concluir a sua casa.
texts.en:
Tomas Paipe S. was born in the city of Inhambane in the province of the same name in southern Mozambique. He is a widower and the father of three children, two of whom attend school. He attended school through the 6th grade, but had to leave school because his family no longer had the economic resources for him to continue. He lives in his own house with his family and isn't financially responsible for anyone else. 
He left Inhambane for Boane in order to fulfill his compulsory military service, and later built his house there. He has retired from the military and receives a pension from the Ministry of the Defense in the amount of 4397 meticals, which he uses to cover household expenses. Occasionally he is able to save a little in his bank account.
He's never received loans from other banks. He learned about Hluvuku from friends who are also Hluvuku clients. This is his fourth loan, in the amount of 15,000 meticals, which he intends to use to purchase construction materials (sand, stone, cement, etc.) to continue improving his house. His previous loans were for 2500, 5000, and 15,000 meticals, which he also used on his dwelling.
He's committed to paying this loan off on time so that he'll be eligible for others in the future. He intends to request additional loans to finish his house.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials (sand, stone, cement, etc.).

loans.name: Abel

texts.en:
Abel O. O. is a 33-year-old single man. He rears poultry so as to earn a living. He has been in the business for 11 years. So far, he has employed two people in his family.  

Being a member of Faulu Kenya, he is able to save his money with a group. Most of all, he is able get a loan easily. He hopes to open a big poultry farm in the future. He has requested 50,000 KES to add laying hens and enlarge the poultry house.

loans.use: to buy laying hens and enlarge the poultry house

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah is a married lady with two children.  

For two years, she has been operating a hardware business with one employee. She gained experience for running the hardware business because she was previously employed in a hardware shop. 

She hopes to import hardware materials in the future. She has requested 50,000 KES to buy paints, nails, nuts and bolts.  Deborah's photo was taken when she had brought in new stock.

loans.use: To buy paints, nails, nuts and bolts

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
For one who values dreams like gold, every effort is necessary. Josephine J., 45, exerts the best effort she can give to attain her dreams for her business and for her family. Josephine reached second year in college and is now married to Johnimar, a goldsmith. Together they live in Dasmarinas, Cavite.

Josephine helps Johnimar in marketing the gold jewelry he makes. Their shop, which has been operating for 11 years now, is located on a nearby barangay in Cavite. Josephine hires four employees to help with the making of gold accessories and other items. Also, she sells products ranging from clothes to small house appliances directly to customers she knows in her community. Another source of income for their family is selling electronic loads for mobile phones. With these small-scale businesses, Josephine is able to earn around PHP 12,500 on average monthly.

To help her grow her goldsmith shop, Josephine is requesting a 38,000 PHP loan. In keeping with her learning from the lessons CCT gives on entrepreneurship, Josephine will use this loan to pay for materials necessary in making gold jewelry. Josephine sees this as a big help to her capital, which will eventually impact her business income greatly.

Indeed, there are a lot of challenges every micro entrepreneur faces every day, but Josephine chooses to focus on her golden dreams. It is her desire for her business to become famous in their place and eventually gain more branches in other towns. 

For her family, she prays to have their own dream house in time. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase materials for goldsmithing

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe is a married woman living in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato with her family. She has been raising pigs for 30 years. She sells the pigs at the market. Fe's husband is a farmer and she helps him maintain their rice farm.

Fe plans to use her loan to purchase pig feed, rice seeds and fertilizers. Fe does her best to improve their businesses.

loans.use: to purchase pig feed, rice seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for clothing store preparation.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase merchandise (bales of used clothing for children and adults).

loans.name: Go Before Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you members of the “Go Before” group. These are small-scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each in order to invest in their businesses. 

Isatu C. is the leader of this group. Isatu is 65 years old and married, with five children. Three are in primary school and two are in secondary school. 

Isatu sells dishes, cups, pots, etc., and has been doing this business for 35 years now. With the help of this loan, Isatu will invest in her business by buying the above mentioned items in large quantity to add to her current stock.  

(Also included in the right of the photo is loan officer Zainab B. handing over the loan to the borrowers.)

loans.use: to buy dishes, cups, pots, etc., in large quantity to add to her current stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Growth is very important in business as in life in general. Lourdes C., a CCT* community partner, sees its value in her life. At 57, she has some college learning to look back to, but what helps her a lot with her business now is her involvement in the entrepreneurial trainings and Bible studies in CCT. 

Lourdes is married to Bonifacio, and together they have three children. Their family resides in Dasmarinas, Cavite.

Lourdes is part of the food industry on the local level. She sells smoked fish and dried fish along with cold cuts and frozen food. Because her sales depend on the demand of her regular customers in the community, her income varies every month, but it averages roughly PHP 11,300.

With no employees to help her, Lourdes has been working perseveringly for ten years now.

A loan worth PHP 20,000 is deemed necessary for Lourdes to help her grow her business. She then applies for such, intending to use the money to purchase more quantities of in-demand food such as frozen food and smoked fish. She wants to do this so that she will not run out of stocks in case her customers order more than what they usually buy.

It is difficult for Lourdes to face the months of vacation, because then her sales drop low. But she strives to come up with strategies to make her business continue gaining profits even during vacation. She aspires for continuous improvement in her business and increasing growth in profits because her family depends on it for their daily needs. 

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase more quantities of dried fish and frozen food

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 37 years old and married with four children. She has been farming for five years. Through Faulu Kenya, she has expanded her business. She has also managed to provide an education to her children. In five years, she hopes to become the major supplier of cereals in her home town. She is also looking forward to adding more cows to her farm. She has requested 50,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy a dairy cow.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
One can see life as a fabric into which either golden threads or burlap are woven. For Geraldine L., 35, each thread is valuable as it makes her and her family's lives worth living. Aside from being a micro-entrepreneur, Geraldine is also a wife to Samuel, a car air conditioner technician, and a mother to three children, one of whom is in high school while the other two go to elementary school. Their family lives in Dasmarinas, Cavite. 

Doormat making is Geraldine's main business. She uses scrap cloth to produce beautiful doormats that are sold at prices afforded by her fellow community members. Geraldine has been operating this business for three years now in their home in Dasmarinas. 

Other than doormat making, she is also into direct selling. She brings with her catalogs of the apparel brand Board Walk and other beauty brands, gets orders from customers in the neighborhood, purchases the orders, and delivers the products to the customers. She earns profits out of the commission. Summing it all up, Geraldine earns a net income of 7,900 Philippine pesos (PHP) every month. 

To help her grow her doormat making business, Geraldine decides to loan an amount of 14,000 PHP. She believes that with the entrepreneurial training and spiritual support CCT* gives her, she will be able to channel the loan into appropriate business measures and increase her income. She plans to purchase more cloth in order to be able to produce more doormats. Part of the loan will also go to purchasing more Board Walk products for her direct selling business. 

Given the challenges Geraldine refuses to specifically mention, she then focuses on making the golden threads and the burlap of her life come together to produce a majestic fabric, the fulfillment of her dreams. Simply, this includes profound growth for her business and a college diploma for each of her dear children. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase cloth for doormat weaving and home products for resale

loans.name: Helena Veronica

texts.pt:
Helena Veronica M. nasceu na cidade de Xai Xai, Província de Gaza, sul de Moçambique casada mãe de 7 filhos de idades entre 08 a 38 anos, os mais novos ainda  continuam a estudar. Frequenta 10ª classe não continuou quando jovem  devido a falta de condicoes financeiras. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém para alem de seus filhos.

Saiu de Gaza para  Maputo ainda muito jovem com seus pais, depois de se casar mudou se para Boane com a sua familia. Tem um negocio proprio de venda de loiça de cozinha ha mais de 10 anos. Não possui nenhum empregado e tem um rendimento mensal de 3.500.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e consegue poupar uma parte na sua conta bancaria porque tem ajuda do seu marido que trabalha na Eletricidade de Moçambique.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de sua vizinha que é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu primeiro empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar mercadoria (pratos, copos, talheres, panelas e outros) para aumentar a quantidade de seu stock.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente para poder aceder a outros créditos no futuro. Pretende solicitar novos empréstimos para ampliar a sua banca.
texts.en:
Helena Veronica M. was born in the city of Xai Xai, Gaza Province in southern Mozambique. She is married and the mother of 7 children between the ages of 8 and 38. The youngest children are still in school. Helena attends 10th grade. She did not finish school when she was young because of financial difficulties. She lives in her own house with her family and does not support anyone other than her children.

When she was still very young, she left Gaza to move to Maputo with her parents. After marrying, she moved to Boane with her family. For more than 10 years Helena has had her own business selling kitchen ware. She has no employees and has a monthly income of about 3,500 meticais. She uses this money for household expenses and manages to save some in her bank account because her husband, who works at the utilities company Eletricidade de Moçambique, helps her.

She has never had loans from other banks, and she learned about Hluvuku through her neighbor, who is a customer of this institution. This is Helena's first Hluvuku loan, and she is asking for 20,000 meticais. She intends to buy merchandise (plates, glasses, flatware, pans and other items) to increase her stock.

She promises to pay on time so she can take out other loans in the future. She plans to ask for new loans so she can expand her sales stand.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise (plates, glasses, flatware, pans, etc.)

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce is 48 years old, married and has two children who are 28 and 29 years old. She is grateful for the help she has received from Faulu Kenya because it has allowed her to put both her children through school. Joyce earns a living by farming and by running a small retail shop, and has applied for a loan for Kes. 35,000 to buy sugar, cooking fat, salt and soap to sell to her customers. Her long-term goal is to increase her income by expanding her farm.

loans.use: To buy sugar, cooking fat, salt and soap to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Kiprono

texts.en: Kiprono is 33 years old, single and has worked as a farmer for the last three years. He grows pineapples and bananas which he sells in a local market, along with milk that comes from a cow which he owns. He lives in the town of Litein in southern Kenya. He is applying for a loan for 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure another cow because he believes he can improve his living standards by producing and selling more milk.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Bakyara Twekambe Group B, Ibanda

texts.en:
N. Kurusam is the leader of Bakyara Twekambe group B in Ibanda. She is 28 years old and married with two children who are twins. Kurusam has had a grocery store in Kyaruhanga that sells foodstuffs and other domestic items for four years; she is able to make 180,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) as weekly income. Her customers are basically the general public. 

Before starting her business, she sold her 10 goats and got an additional 100,000 UGX from her father. She is also involved in the rearing of chickens. Being hard working has enabled her to succeed. She hopes for an educated family and expanded business and at the moment, she needs a loan to be able to purchase more grocery products.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery products for resale

loans.name: Sebjamol

texts.ru: Пардаева Себжамол проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 46 лет. Замужем, имеет троих детей. Образование-среднее. Она зарабатывает путем разведения крупнорогатого скота. Она в основном разводит скот в дальнейшем для продажи. Этим видом деятельности она занимается три года. Кредит просит для закупа крупнорогатого скота, чтобы увеличить их количества.
texts.en: Sebjamol P. lives in Shahrituz. She is 46 years old, married, and has three children. She has a high school education.  She earns a living raising cattle. She raises cattle for resale. She has been doing this work for three years. She is taking out a loan to buy cattle to increase her herd.

loans.use: to buy cattle

loans.name: Takilifinoh Group

texts.en: Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT) is a partner of Kiva.org in the town of Makeni in northern Sierra Leone. The five women you see here are all members of the Takilifinoh loan group and are small-scale entrepreneurs who are applying for a loan of SLL 500,000 to expand their businesses. Fatmata J., who leads the group, is 35 years old, has five children and has made a living for the last five years by selling rice, palm-oil, pepper and other items. She will use her portion of this loan to buy more items to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To buy rice, palm-oil, pepper and other items in bulk to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Gelinda

texts.en:
Gelinda is a 48-year-old married woman living in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She has two children aged 24 and 21. She is engaged in farming and has been growing rice for 20 years. She also raises pigs in her backyard. Gelinda sells her rice and pigs at the market.

Gelinda's loan will be used to purchase fertilizer, piglets and feed. She hopes for her piggery and rice farm to grow.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, piglets and feed

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: For the last three years, Margaret M. M. has earned a living by making dresses in the town of Matuu. She is married, earns a monthly income of KES. 10,000, and is applying for her first loan to buy more materials to make new dresses to sell to her customers. Her goal is to have a future that is financially stable by continuing to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy materials to make dresses to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Development Group

texts.en: Adama K., who leads this five-person loan group, is 35 years old and lives in the city of Makeni. She is married, has four children and has made a living by selling ready-to-wear-clothes for the last several years. She will use her portion of this loan, her first, to expand her business by buying more clothing to sell to her customers. The other members of this group will also use their portions of this loan to expand their businesses and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To expand several small businesses.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
This is Susan G., 44, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Donato G., a tricycle driver, and is the mother of three children, who are all studying at the public elementary school nearby. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Susan, as she herself has been an elementary graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children. 

Susan operates a food stall. She offers basic and mostly in-demand viands for breakfast and lunch in her community. In the Philippines, a food stall is usually found in communities both small and big. Filipinos who are always on the rush early in the morning prefer to buy ready-to-eat food from a food stall like Susan's to cooking for themselves. Serving her community, she earns an estimated net income of around 11,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) monthly. 

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan. She plans to use this loan to buy more raw ingredients for her food stall business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Susan dreams of being able to give all of her children a good and high-quality education through all of her hard work in her business. She also prays that her children who already have their own families will be able to have their own house and lot for their respective families. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship meeting * where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for food stall sales

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy oil, rice, beans, soap, sugar... for his store

loans.name: Lovetta

texts.en:
Lovetta is 31 years old and lives in the Congo Town area. She's married and her husband is an auto mechanic who works at a local garage. They have two girls who are two and thirteen currently attending school. She and her husband have to struggle to make ends meet. 

Lovetta started a small grocery store in 2006 where she sells, soap, biscuits, cold drinks, oil, etc., but not every day does business seem to go very well. 

Lovetta is requesting a loan to purchase rice, soap, soft drinks, etc.

She hopes to be a very strong business-woman, and plans to build a store and a house for her children in the future.

loans.use: to buy rice, soap, soft drinks, etc.

loans.name: Korkine Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the "Korkine" group. They are small-scale businesspeople based in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profits, and consequently improve on their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Mohamed L.. Mohamed is age 40. He is married to a businesswoman and the couple has three children. Mohamed has been a businessman for six years now. He sells spare parts for bikes. He has requested this loan in order to buy spare parts in larger quantity to add to his business.

loans.use: to buy spare parts in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fish, meat, and palm oil at wholesale to add to her business

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia N. is from the village of Bonbon, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 54 years old. Virginia is married and has two school-aged children. Virginia owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling green bananas & coconut wines in the local community. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2009, Virginia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from HSPFI, which was for 13,000 PHP and was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. 

This loan will be her fifth from HSPFI. Virginia is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to to purchase additional yellow and green bananas. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI: 

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional yellow and green bananas

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and to hire workers

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza L. is from the village of Bonbon, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 35 years old. Analiza is married and has three school-aged children. Analiza sells ready-to-wear clothing, sandals, sleepers, & shoe products in her community. Analiza has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2011, Analiza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Analiza is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional t-shirts & blouses. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Analiza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI: 

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional t-shirts & blouses

loans.name: Zokirjon

texts.ru: Султонов Зокиржон житель района Шахритус. Ему 45 лет. Он женат. Имеет троих детей. У него среднее образование. Он более 6 лет занимается растениеводством. Арендует участок земли, где сеет злаковые культуры. Целью кредита является покупка минеральных удобрений, топлива, семян арбуза и ячменя для посева.
texts.en: Zokirjon S. lives in Shahrituz. He is 45 years old, married, and has three children. He has a secondary education. He has been working in agriculture for more than six years. He rents a plot of land where he sows grain. He is taking out a loan to buy mineral fertilizers, fuel, watermelon seeds, and barley to plant.

loans.use: to buy mineral fertilizers, fuel, watermelon seeds, and barley to plant.

loans.name: Choko

texts.en:
Choko is 33 years old and lives in the Congo Town area. She is married, has three children, and did not finish high school. She has a little beauty parlor  just outside of her house while her husband earns a living from playing a drum at a church in their community.

Choko is requesting a loan to purchase more cosmetics and used clothes for her business. She wishes to build her own house and send her children to the best schools in the country.

loans.use: to purchase more cosmetics and used clothes for her business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy palm oil, rice, beans, peanuts, etc. in bulk

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet R. is from the village of Puntod, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 41 years old. Juliet is married and has eight school-aged children. Juliet sells green bananas & coconut wines in her community. Juliet has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2010, Juliet joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from HSPFI, which was for 8,000 PHP and was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. 

This loan will be her third from HSPFI. Juliet is requesting 4,000 PHP which will be used to to purchase additional green bananas. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI: 

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional green bananas

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine A. O. is a sole proprietor business lady who is a tailor.  She offers her tailoring services at the Kariobangi Market in Nairobi.  She has been in this business for the last 10 years.  Her monthly income is KES 40,000.    

Josephine is 46 years old, married to Samson Odera, and they have three children.   She was introduced to KADET by a friend.  Josephine has a good credit history with KADET LTD and this is her fourth loan from KADET.  She plans to use this loan to buy clothes materials to make dresses for sale. 

In the future, Josephine hopes to grow her business and own a very big material shop.

loans.use: to buy materials to make dresses for sale

loans.name: Teimuraz

texts.en:
Teimuraz M. is 53 years old. He lives in the village of Pshaveli, Kakheti Region. Teimuraz is married and lives with his wife, Leila, his mother, his 28-year-old son, his daughter-in-law and two grandchildren – a 7-year-old boy and a  5-year-old girl. The children go to school.

Sheep-breeding is the main source of income for the family. Teimuraz sells sheep's milk cheese, wool, and lambs. Also, the family has agricultural land with an area of 3 ha, where maize is grown. Along with the above-mentioned, Teimuraz in involved in another family business;  they sell flour locally. The total monthly income of the M.’s family amounts to 1200 Laris. 

Teimuraz requested a loan from Credo for plowing the land where maize will be sown. The other part of the loan will be used for purchasing feed for sheep. The increase in income will  contribute indirectly to the further expansion of their sheep-breeding business – earned income will be used to cover family daily expenses and Teimuraz won’t have to sell the lambs. This will expand the herd of sheep and thus the income received from sales of sheep cheese and wool will increase.

loans.use: to purchase fuel for land cultivation and feed for sheep.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
This is Carmelita L., 53, a resident of Gamban Extension, Cabrera, Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Romeo L., a mason, and is the mother of two children who are studying in high school and college.  At this time, Carmelita is working hard to be able to send her children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Carmelita, as she herself has been a college graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance that parents can leave to their children.

Carmelita has been in the direct selling business for a year now.  She sells food supplements and other herbal products to her friends, neighbors and people in the local community.  Carmelita buys these items at a dealer's price and sells them at the price published in the product catalogs.  Her earnings is based on sales commission.  She also manages a small mineral water refilling station which is adjacent to her house. Monthly, she earns an estimated net income of around 11,000 PHP.  

To help her continue the operations of her businesses, Carmelita is requesting a 12,000 PHP loan.  She plans to use this loan to buy boxes of food supplements ordered in advance by her customers.  She will also use part of this loan to pay for more cases of mineral water for her refilling business. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her businesses.

Carmelita dreams of being able to give all her children a high-quality education through her hard work in her businesses.  As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group’s weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received. 

*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy food supplements and mineral water to resell

loans.name: Pelagie

texts.en:
Pelagie is 36 years old. She is married with two children between the ages of 5 and 7 years old. She is a carpenter. She makes and repairs home and office furniture (e.g. tables, chairs, beds, wardrobes, etc). Her husband is a businessman. Her business is well organized. She employs two people in her business. She works from 8am until 6pm every day and has three years of experience.

Pelagie has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to repair more office furniture like tables, chairs, wardrobes and so on. The loan will enable her to add to her stock of wood. This will enable her to satisfy demands easily. Pelagie encounters some difficulties with not being able to satisfy demand for her goods and with customers who delay payment. She says that once she gets this loan, she will make profit, pay school fees for her children and improve the welfare of her family.

loans.use: To add to her stock of wood

loans.name: Bakyara Twekambe Group C, Ibanda

texts.en:
Issa M. is the leader of Bakyara Twekambe group C, Ibanda. He is 31 years old, married, and has 5 children.  Issa has a butcher shop where he sells meat with the help of his two boys.   His butcher shop is on the main street behind the old taxi park in Ibandaand.  He is able to make an income of 200,000 UGX per week.  He is also involved in the sale of goats. 

Issa is grateful that for the 12 years that he has been in business, he has been able to take good care of his family due to the experience he gained from working with his uncle that helped him improve and grow his business. Issa needs a loan to be able to buy cows and goats for meat and sale.

loans.use: To buy cows and goats for his butcher shop business

loans.name: Pyramide Plus Group

texts.en:
Clément is the leader of a community bank named “Pyramide Plus”.  This group which is composed of 15 microentrepreneurs, united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC with the goal of developing their businesses.
 
Clément sells second-hand clothing. He started his business in 2005 with the beginning capital of US$60. With hard work and determination, he has succeeded in making it thrive thanks to good management and accumulated profits.  Currently, he earns a profit of $120 every week. 

Clément is a loyal client of IMF HOPE RDC and has received three previous loans which he has successfully repaid.  He intends to use this next loan to increase the inventory for his business by purchasing a second-hand clothing bundle in order to increase his profit. 

Clément is married and is the father of three children aged between 10 months and 6 years old -- one of them is currently going to school. His dream is to open a general boutique and a drugstore in his community.

loans.use: to buy second-hand clothing to resell

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more inventory for his timber business

loans.name: Nima

texts.en:
Nima is a young woman from Deir Al Balah in the Gaza Strip. Nima is a mother of two daughters and one son; Riham, Manar and Muhannad are young school students. Nima and her husband Bassam who appears in the picture here -Nima is a conservative woman as are most Gaza Strip inhabitants- started a grocery store three years ago.

As the three children are growing up and more expenses are to be covered, Nima took out a loan from FATEN to purchase a larger number of items to sell in the store and increase their profit.

loans.use: to purchase goods to sell in their grocery store.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret N. M. has been in the dress-making business for three years and earns monthly income of 12,000 Kenyan shillings (KES). She is 36 and her husband is named Joshua. 

She was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend and she has applied for her first loans from KADET LTD which she intends to use to buy more cloth for making dresses for sale. 

In the future, Margaret hopes to grow her business and diversify it to include a cereal shop.

loans.use: to buy cloth for dressmaking

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex G. is 49 years old. He lives in the village of Ikalto, Telavi District. Alex is married and lives with his wife Mzia, their parents, their 22-year-old son and their daughter-in-law. Alex works as a taxi driver in Telavi. Also, he helps Mzia to manage their  second-hand clothes shop. Their shop is popular in the village as they always provide a variety of good clothes to the villagers. The profit from the shop amounts to 800 Laris per month.

With the requested credit Alex and Mzia will increase the stock in trade in their shop. New stock will insure that the shop will have a sufficient number of customers and a constant flow of income. The profit will be reinvested in further expansion of the shop.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of used clothes.

loans.name: Kagaramira Central Twimukye Group

texts.en:
K. Francis, 35, started his pineapple farming business on a small scale in Kagaramira-Ibanda three years ago. At the beginning, he was selling principally bananas. He made a decision to diversify months later-choosing to grow and sell pineapples. 

The hard working father of three says whilst he was able to make significant ends meet with his modest earnings, he was having shortfalls in the provision of overall welfare to his family and close relatives. Weekly he says this business generates him 60,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) as profit. He says with this loan he is going to purchase more land to expand his pineapple farm.

loans.use: to purchase land to expand his pineapple farm

loans.name: Sulaiman

texts.en:
Sulaiman is a young father of one daughter and three sons. Sulaiman owns a taxi and drives it in Rafah refugee camp in the Gaza Strip. 

Sulaiman took out a loan from FATEN to have the car fixed and be able to work longer hours and transport passengers outside Rafah which will increase the profit and enhance the family's financial situation.

Sulaiman was photographed next to his car.

loans.use: to have his taxi fixed and be able to work longer hours.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
This is Delia M., 36, a resident of Gamban Riverside, Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Ireneo M., a shoe repairman. They have been blessed with children who are still studying right now. At this time, Delia is working hard to be able to send her children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Delia, as she herself is a high school graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children. 

Delia operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, five pesos' worth of cooking oil or an egg. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at retail piece rates. She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day. 

To help her continue operation of her variety store, she is requesting a 45,000 PHP loan. She plans to use this loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages so as to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Delia dreams of being able to give all of her children a good and high-quality education through all of her hard work in her business. She looks forward to having her children get a stable job someday. Delia also prays for her own commercial space in their public market. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship meeting* where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy grocery items for restocking and expanding her variety store

loans.name: Soley

texts.en:
Soley is 29 years old and lives in the Congo Town area. She's single and her boyfriend works for a construction company; they have two children, a one year old and a five year old. Only the older daughter attends school. 

Soley has been selling cosmetics and footwear for the past seven years.

She is requesting a loan to purchase more cosmetics and a barrel of footwear for her business. She plans to be a medical doctor in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more cosmetics and footwear for her business

loans.name: Zaliko

texts.en:
Zaliko K. is 53 years old. He lives in the village of Akura, Telavi District. He lives with his son, daughter-in-law and 1-year-old grandchild. The only source of income for the family is agricultural activities, led by Zaliko. At the moment they have four calves which will be grown and sold in a couple of months. Besides that, the family owns agricultural land with an area of 11 ha. On part of this land is a vineyard. On other parts strawberries, maize, sunflowers and peaches are grown. All harvested grain and fruit are sold locally.  

Now Zaliko plans to sow maize and sunflowers. With the requested loan he will purchase fuel for a tractor, which will till his land, and seeds for maize and sunflowers. Zaliko hopes that he’ll have a good harvest season. Received profit will be invested in livestock – additional calves will be purchased and raised.

loans.use: to purchase fuel for land cultivation and maize and sunflower seeds.

loans.name: Samar

texts.en:
Samar B. is a mother of two daughters and three sons, Samar's husband, who appears in the picture here as she is a conservative woman, is a Palestinian National Authority employee.

Samar took out a loan from FATEN to purchase furniture for the girls' and boys' room as they are growing and they need better furniture. Samar and her family are known for being a decent family of good reputation.

loans.use: to purchase furniture for the children's rooms.

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
Annie is 38 years old and lives in the Congo Town area. She dropped out of elementary school in grade one. Her husband is presently not working and  he, along with their five children, depend on her for a livelihood. 

Annie is selling food items in a local market, she sells fufu (starchy dumplings made from cassava, yam, plantain or rice that are eaten with soup or stew), oil, and pepper amongst other things. She is requesting a loan to purchase more oil, rice, and fufu for her business. 

She hopes to build her own house and improve her children's education.

loans.use: to purchase more oil, rice and fufu for her business

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is 25 years old and is a widow without children. She has had a restaurant for one year. She employs one person. Rehema works from 8am until 7pm every day. She realized that she lacks sufficient equipment to offer a quality service in her restaurant. 

Rehema has requested her first loan from Kiva partner, Vision Finance Company s.a, to expand her business by buying more goods like sambusa, capati and bread. With this expansion, Rehema hopes to make more profit and this will enable her to buy her own house and save for the future.

loans.use: To purchase more goods like sambusa, capati and bread

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy rice, margi, onions, groundnut, palm oil, etc., at wholesale to add to her current stock

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: This is 45-year-old Martha K.. She is married and has one child, age 12. She has one additional dependent, who is her husband’s relative. For the past seven years, Martha has been selling drinks, plasticware, and provisions such as milk, sugar, margarine, cheese, etc., in the central business district of Freetown. Martha is very determined to continuously improve her business. She opens her business six days a week, eleven hours a day. She would like a loan in the amount of 5,000,000 SLL. Martha requires a loan in order to buy stock for her business in large quantities, which saves her from frequent travel to buy in smaller quantities. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy drinks, provisions, and some plastic utensils

loans.name: Ararati Group

texts.fr: Kihuho E. est entrepreneur, présidente du groupe d’affaire « Ararati »,  âgée de 59 ans, mariée, mère de 8 enfants et tous fréquentent l’école et d’autres ont leur propres foyers. Son mari est un agent de presse attaché au gouvernorat provincial du Nord Kivu. La cliente Kihuho E. est vendeuse des produits divers. Elle s’installe au long de la rue donnant axer aux avenues de son quartier, parfois devant sa maison. Elle vient de réaliser 5 cycles opérationnels en bénéficiant de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner avec des nouveaux produits (10 pairs de souliers, bijoux, habits dames,  habits hommes, habits  de junior, ceintures, etc.).  En plus, elle ambitionne agrandir son entreprise et construire confortablement une maison pour sa famille.  La cliente Kihuho E. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Il sied de signaler que le groupe d’affaire « Ararati » est majoritairement féminin composé de 27 clients. Cependant, certains collègues du marché ont profité de cette photo du groupe pour plus d’ambiance et la solidarité d’où 31 figures visibles..
texts.en:
Kihuho E. is an entrepreneur, leader of the Ararati group. She's 59 years old, married and the mother of eight children, who all attended school. Some are now living on their own. Her husband is a press secretary with the governorate of North Kivu province. Kihuho E. sells various items. She finds a spot along the road leading to her neighborhood, sometimes in front of her house.

She just completed her fifth loan cycle with Kiva's partner, MFI Hekima. She will use this loan to get new supplies (10 pairs of shoes, jewelry, clothing for men, women and children, belts, etc.). Furthermore, she ambitions to expand her business and build a comfortable home for her family. 

Ararati group is composed of 27 members, mostly women. Some colleagues from the market joined in for the photograph to express solidarity, there are thus 31 persons to be seen in the picture.

Kihuho E. thanks Hekima for its actions benefiting the poor who do not get access to classical banks.

loans.use: to by 10 pairs of shoes, jewelry, clothing for men, women and children, belts, etc

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase shaving kit, towels and other needed items.

loans.name: Ayaba

texts.fr: Ayaba est revendeuse de biscuits et de bonbons. Elle à 63ans, mariée à un revendeur elle à  04 enfants en charge. Il ya de cela 12ans qu’elle a démarré son activité. Elle s’approvisionne à Accra et revend  dans sa maison à Attiégou (un quartier du Togo). Malgré son âge, Ayaba sollicite ce deuxième prêt  pour acheter des biscuits et bonbons pour réaliser de bénéfices  et pour assurer l’avenir de ses enfants.
texts.en: Ayaba resells biscuits and candies. She's 63 years old, married to a reseller, and has four children to support. She started her business 12 years ago. She gets her supplies in Accra, and resells at her home in Attiégou, a neighborhood in Togo. Despite her age, Ayaba is seeking a second loan to buy biscuits and candies, in order to turn a profit and ensure the future of her children.

loans.use: to buy biscuits and candies

loans.name: Cloche Plus Group

texts.en:
Erick, age 24 and single, is the president of the community bank “Cloche Plus,” which is composed of 17 members united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC, with the goal of developing their businesses. 

Erick started his business in 2003. He sells miscellaneous goods at the market located northeast of the city of Kinshasa. He is a loyal client of IMF HOPE RDC who has already received three different loans and has repaid them properly. He intends to use the next loan to reinforce his business by purchasing some items that are needed by his customers and reselling them with the aim of increasing his profits. Each week, his business brings in a profit of US $130 per month.
 
Erick’s ambition is to open a small company in his environment.

loans.use: to increase the inventory of his business by buying some items and reselling them for a profit

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Annalie

texts.en:
This is Annalie M., 25, who desires stability for her personal and family life. She is happily married to Joemarie M. and they are blessed with two children who are currently studying in public elementary and high school. Together they live on Rodriguez Street, Pasay City, Philippines. 

Annalie has managed a computer shop for almost two years now. She rents her computers by the hour to her community for surfing, social networking, and even doing research for students. She earns an estimated net income of around 1000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) a month. 

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a 30,000 PHP loan. She is planning to use this loan to purchase two additional computer units. She expects a boost in her business income through the proper use of this loan. 

Annalie prays that her children will become God fearing individuals and will be able to finish their studies up to college through her hard work on doing her business. She also desires a good and happy life for her entire family. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship  meeting* where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community members are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners that meet on a weekly basis. The fellowship groups gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy two additional computers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more palm oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy DVDs and VCDs for his business

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is a young woman from Jabalia refugee camp in Gaza Strip. Fatima's husband has a construction supplies store. He sells the wood used in construction.

Fatima's husband, who appears in the picture here as Fatima is a conservative woman as are most Gaza Strip inhabitants, needed $1500 to purchase more wood to answer his customers' demand. Fatima took out the loan from FATEN so her husband can purchase the amount he needs.

loans.use: to purchase wood sold by her husband for construction.

loans.name: Babydee

texts.en:
Babydee is 22 years old and live in the Paynesville area. She is single and has no children. She stopped school in the 9th grade.
Babydee sells used clothes and fish. Sometimes she experiences losses, but most of the time she has very good sales. She is requesting a loan to purchase more used clothes and fish for her businesses. She plans to buy a piece of land and build her own house in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more used clothes and fish.

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en: Godfrey is a 33-year-old married man with four children. He lives in a semi-permanent house in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda. He is a produce trader, a business in which he has been involved for 15 years, having begun as a subsistence farmer. Godfrey wants to educate his children and build a permanent house. He is requesting a loan to buy maize for resale.

loans.use: to buy maize for resale.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a 33-year-old married man with two children. He lives in a semi-permanent house in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda, with the eight people he takes care of. He is a produce trader, a business in which he has been involved for ten years, having begun with 600,000 UGX that he had saved. He now boasts of a capital of 6,000,000 UGX. John wants to educate his children and build a permanent house. He is requesting a loan to buy maize produce for resale.

loans.use: to buy maize for resale.

loans.name: Al-Ameer

texts.en:
Al-Ameer is a young man from Jabalia Refugee Camp in the Gaza Strip. Al-Ameer runs a computer store where he sells computer accessories and fixes computers.

Al-Ameer took out a loan from FATEN to purchase computer accessories and parts he needs to fix computers with. This will increase the profit of the store where Al-Ameer is photographed.

loans.use: to purchase computer accessories to sell in his store.

loans.name: Sairan Rysbaeva's Group

texts.en:
Sairan R., 49, is the leader of this group. She is a mother of four children, the oldest of whom is 19 years old. For six years, since the start-up of her business, Sairan and her children have worked hard for the major part of the daytime. The family buys young calves, breeds them and resells them at a higher price. Sairan says that the hardest part is covering all the costs related to feeding and providing healthy conditions for cattle breeding. Approximately every month, Sairan takes a head of cattle for sale to a local market. A couple of years ago she increased her stock from three heads to ten heads. The initial capital of 4,000 KGS was returned in a month of operating the business. Sairan believes in a bright future for her business, therefore decided to broaden her stock by applying for a loan from Kiva.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more oil, cream perm, paper etc. for her business.

loans.name: Noah

texts.en: Noah is a 34-year-old married man with four children. He owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has run a retail shop for five years. His hardships include debtors, price fluctuations, inflation and high transport costs. His vision is to have a large-scale retail shop and to educate his children. Noah needs a loan to buy beers and sodas for resale.

loans.use: to buy beers and sodas for resale.

loans.name: Justus

texts.en: Justus is a 30-year-old married man with one child. He owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in business selling stationery and running a computer training center for two years. He started with one computer but now has four computers. The hardship he faces is high taxes. Justus' vision is to expand his business and make a sustainable income. Justus intends to use his loan to build rental houses.

loans.use: to build rental houses.

loans.name: Eric

texts.en: Eric is a 29-year-old married man with three children. He owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has run a retail shop for two years. The hardships he faces include bad debtors, price fluctuations and high transport costs. His vision is to have a large-scale retail shop and to educate his children. Eric will use his loan to buy soap, sugar and rice for resale.

loans.use: to buy soap, sugar and rice for resale.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is a 30-year-old hardworking man living in a rented house in Kasese, Uganda. The responsibility to look after the family rests solely with him, and he desires to have an educated family and to build a house.

Robert started a retail shop three years ago with capital of 100,000 shillings, an amount that has since grown to 800,000 shillings. He needs the loan to buy bread and rice for his shop and dreams of one day becoming a wholesaler. High taxes are his main challenge.

loans.use: to buy bread and rice to sell.

loans.name: Kalbubu Beishenbekova's Group

texts.en:
Kalbubu B., 53, is the leader of this group. She resides in the town of Kochkor, which in the Soviet era was known for its oil wells. The posters saying “Oil is the strength of people” still hang around the town. For the most part, the town is rural and therefore the main occupations are cattle breeding and cultivating land.
Kalbubu is a typical resident of this town. She lives with her husband, a security worker in a local high school, and their three adult children, two of whom are temporarily in the capital for work. Kalbubu's oldest son is a member of the town's farming community and helps her in taking proper care of the cattle. She started raising cattle in 1990 after the birth of her second child. She had initial capital of 10,000 KGS. Since then she has experienced many different times, some when profit was negative and some when her business prospered. At this moment, Kalbubu receives 5,000 KGS of monthly profit. Her requested loan will be used to purchase more cattle so that she can broaden her stock.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy merchandise (beans, oil, rice, peanuts, etc.)

loans.name: Soliboy

texts.en:
S. Soliboy is 42 years old. He is married and the father of two children. He is a livestock breeder who buys and sells cattle from different market places. He has been in this business for the last 20 years. His main customers are butchers and livestock farmers. With this loan from Kiva, Soliboy plans to increase his herd of cattle for trade and, if possible, open up his own butchery. This, he says, will increase his turnover. He plans to see his children go through higher education and be able to get good jobs, unlike himself. 

More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit:  www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace, a 27-year-old single mother with one child, rents a house in Kasese, Uganda where she has operated a retail shop for seven years. She began the business with capital of 200,000 shillings and a loan acqiured from Hofokam of 300,000 shillings, and she now has 2,000,000 shillings as her working capital.

Grace's main hardship is limited finances to meet the demands of her customers, and she intends to use the loan to buy rice and sugar to sell. Her vision is to become a wholesaler, educate her child, and build a house.

loans.use: to buy rice and sugar to sell.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
